how_to_use.title: Creating a Profile
how_to_use.description: Open the Profiles screen and tap 'Add'. Enter your name, age, gender, height, weight, and relation. BMI is calculated automatically.

how_to_use.title: Adding Vitals
how_to_use.description: Go to the Vitals screen, select a profile, and enter Pulse, Blood Pressure, Temperature, and SpO₂. Values can be measured using devices like BP monitors and oximeters.

how_to_use.title: Tracking Hydration
how_to_use.description: Use quick-add buttons (+100ml, +250ml, +500ml) to log water intake. The app will remind you to drink at optimal times.

how_to_use.title: How to Measure Pulse
how_to_use.description: Place two fingers on the inside of the wrist to feel the pulse. Count beats for 60 seconds. If you have a smartwatch or fitness band, you can use it to measure continuously and more accurately.

how_to_use.title: Using a Home Blood Pressure Monitor
how_to_use.description: Sit comfortably and rest for 5 minutes before measuring. Keep the cuff at heart level and follow the device instructions. Record at the same time each day to observe trends.

how_to_use.title: Temperature Measurement and Fever Guide
how_to_use.description: Use a digital thermometer. Normal body temperature is 36.5–37.5 °C. If temperature is > 38.0 °C for adults, take rest and fluids — consult a healthcare provider if it persists or is very high.

how_to_use.title: SpO₂ (Oxygen Saturation) Measurement
how_to_use.description: Use a pulse oximeter on the fingertip. Normal SpO₂ is ≥95%. Values < 90% are critical; seek urgent medical attention. Avoid nail polish and cold hands for accurate reading.

how_to_use.title: Hydration Tips
how_to_use.description: Aim for 2000–3000 ml per day depending on activity. Use quick-add buttons in the Hydration screen. Avoid excessive intake (>4L/day) without medical advice. Drink small amounts regularly rather than large amounts rarely.

how_to_use.title: Interpreting Your Charts
how_to_use.description: Line charts show trends over time: look for upward/downward trends (e.g., rising BP). Pie chart and family overview show the distribution of normal/warning/critical vitals. Tap a pie slice to view detailed issues and recommendations.

diet_plans.title: Balanced Diet
diet_plans.description: Include a mix of proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals in your meals. Divide into 3 main meals and 2 snacks daily.

diet_plans.title: Low-Salt Diet
diet_plans.description: For high BP, reduce salt intake. Replace packaged snacks with fruits, and season with herbs instead of salt.

diet_plans.title: Hydrate & Rest
diet_plans.description: Drink water, rest, and monitor temperature. Seek medical care if fever persists.

workout_tips.title: Daily Walking
workout_tips.description: Aim for 30 minutes of brisk walking every day. Track your steps with a smartwatch or phone app.

workout_tips.title: Strength Training
workout_tips.description: Do light strength training (push-ups, squats, resistance bands) 2–3 times per week for muscle and bone health.

workout_tips.title: Rest & Breathing
workout_tips.description: Sit quietly and do slow deep breathing for 5-10 minutes. Repeat if heart rate remains high.

workout_tips.title: Low-salt Diet & Walk
workout_tips.description: Reduce salt intake and take a brisk 20-30 minute walk daily.

workout_tips.title: Seek Medical Help
workout_tips.description: Low oxygen detected. Contact healthcare services or visit emergency care if breathing difficulty occurs.

health_standards.title: BMI
health_standards.description: Calculated using height & weight. Categories: underweight, normal, overweight, obese.
